title: Monday, 20th February, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Hi

PM11:05am

Hi

PM11:06am

So a belated welcome to Markets LIve

11:05 am
PM11:06am

Yeah, it's the Monday after the Friday before

PM11:06am

Whacky stuff eh?

PM11:06am

Have a chart of that

11:06 am
PM11:06am

https://ftalphavil...creenShot046-2.bmp

PM11:06am

Sorry, you'll have to click that

PM11:06am

Just the two day move in Unilever

11:06 am
PM11:07am

I bet some of you are thinking how Bryce might top Friday's hit

PM11:07am

Well I should tell you

PM11:07am

When a journalist comes out with a monster story

11:07 am
PM11:07am

And $147bn takeover attempt is a monster

PM11:07am

He/her next story in invariably a dud

BE11:07am

Omg smile

11:07 am
PM11:07am

But Bryce might be different!

BE11:08am

You make a fair point. I'll try not to get any stories for a while, just to build back the safety buffer.

BE11:08am

Anyway, let's not dwell overly on Friday's silliness.

11:08 am
BE11:09am

Frankly, I'm quite happy to have given the Sunday papers something to write about. Beyond that, there's not much to say.

BE11:10am

Though perhaps ..... Maybe we can repeat a point we've noted on here quite a lot over the years.

BE11:10am

Journalists are the last to find out about stuff.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

That's very important.

BE11:10am

And it seems not to be widely accepted.

PM11:10am

Leaks happen; don't shoot the messenger

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Yep. And it seems difficult to accept partly because journalistic egos are elephantine and fragile.

BE11:11am

The thing is, if people directly inside a deal are stonewalling journalists, they're only serving to keep a crooked market crooked.

PM11:11am

And enhance the profits of those dealing on inside information

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Exactly. A lying or fillibustering Financier can quite effectively stop stuff getting into the press.

BE11:11am

But if the press has wind of it, it's already in the market. Always.

BE11:12am

Which is why we sometimes need to adopt a guerrilla strategy, such as we did on Friday.

11:11 am
PM11:12am

We are (almost) the last to know

BE11:12am

Well, "last" is a relative term I guess. So anyway, we can spend the morning luxuriating in being first.

BE11:12am

Perhaps we could start a deal of the week Podcast. Give us some space to really bask in our egos.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Or we could just get on with where we are today.

Unilever PLC (ULVR:LSE): Last: 3,525, down 272.5 (-7.18%), High: 3,554, Low: 3,454, Volume: 4.25m
BE11:13am

So, the weekend press on this was terrible! (mostly).

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Loads of stuff about how Kraft only wants the food side (really!?)

BE11:14am

Loads of stuff about Dutch regulation and such, all of which seems sketchy and now of course totally irrelevant.

BE11:14am

Plenty of stuff about Kraft putting it direct to the shareholders, which ....... well, clearly ..... I don't need to talk about how wrong that take was.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Let's retread through some sellside, of various qualities.

BE11:15am

Here's Natixis

BE11:15am

We think that if Unilever had wanted/been able to sell part of the food to Kraft in exchange for definitive withdrawal of the merger bid, it would have done so. Unilever’s management is not under pressure and this withdrawal by Kraft Heinz shows the degree to which the recovery initiated since 2008 is sound.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

[Scratch chin emoji]

BE11:16am

The terms of the release do not give reasons. The Unilever Board stated on Friday that the bid clearly undervalued the group and that it made no strategic sense. Yet with a bid offering an 18% premium to Thursday’s closing price but which only showed an 18e EV/EBITDA multiple of 15x, Kraft had the potential to make a convincing proposition. We see the following reasons for the backtracking: 1) clear cultural incompatibility (the ZBB with the USLP?), 2) lack of strategic rationale (it would have been a move back fifteen years into the past for Unilever) and 3) the limited capacity to raise the cash portion of the bid whilst the project would have struggled to convince Unilever’s shareholders. On our estimates, this project would have raised net debt for the new ensemble by close to $120bn, i.e. to 5.3x 18e EBITDA after synergies (6% of Unilever’s sales) and to 6.2x before synergies. Had Kraft Heinz dug its heels into the ground, this would have led to ‘war’ with scarce capacity to arouse the appetite of shareholders who wold have been reluctant to receive payment in insubstantial paper.

BE11:17am

This merger would have been clearly positive for L’Oréal
(Neutral) and Beiersdorf (Buy), which would have profited from the distraction of such a move at Unilever. Nestlé (Neutral) could change its stance after having stated on Thursday that the time is not right to make acquisitions. The speculative interest in Danone (Buy) could perhaps increase: the implied valuation of Fresh dairy is almost zero and the shares’ performance is not as effective defence as for Unilever. That said, it is likely that the target of reference shareholders of Kraft Heinz was to find a target sufficiently large target to dilute itself in a less fragile entity (ZBB is not a viable strategy!). Danone's market cap. is three times smaller than Unilever’s.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

And Credit Suisse.

BE11:17am

■ So what next? Unilever has been given a sharp wakeup call that it cannot disregard. Its reluctance to engage with Kraft Heinz (KHC) is understandable, but will it now feel it needs to offer something else to its shareholders?
■ At the very least the prospect of KHC taking its leverage to over 6x Ebitda begs the question: is Unilever making best use of its balance sheet on behalf of investors? Moving to 3x Ebitda would allow Unilever to do a €20 billion share buy-back or a €7 per share special dividend (17% yield). The former would be double digit accretive, the latter only c7% dilutive.
■ Or might this encourage Unilever to be more aggressive on M&A? Whilst KHC appears to have (irrevocably?) walked away, it is clear that investors are willing to back big deals (eg BAT/Reynolds and Reckitt/Mead).
■ Might management even contemplate making a commitment to demerge into FoodCo and HPCCo? Two businesses that might then have licence to accelerate their own inorganic developments.
■ What this approach does tell us is that KHC’s appetite is far from satiated, and size is no obstacle at all to their ambitions. Their presence will likely continue to loom heavily over all industry participants.
■ We raise our price target by 5% to €42 (PLC price target to £35.90), and maintain our Neutral rating, in recognition that you cannot set the clocks back. We expect Unilever to respond to this episode by releasing some value to shareholders (some of whom no doubt are disappointed that the prospect of a control premium evaporated so soon after it first appeared).

BE11:18am

And Cazenove.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

As the market looks beyond Unilever, to where KHC can deploy its cash OR where market participants may consider a further consolidation in the space in the pursuit of size/growth opportunities, we take a look at European Food/HPC universe, though we add a caveat that none of these companies have mentioned any interest from KHC or indeed any other company/PE player. We would also flag that our intention is not to put any of the companies below ‘into play’ but rather to highlight key areas investors might be interested in.

PM11:19am

We would also flag that our intention is not to put any of the companies below ‘into play’

PM11:19am

Course not

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Why would JP Morgan Cazenove want to encourage companies to pursue massively dilutive and value destructive cross-border M&A?

BE11:20am

Why on earth would JP Morgan Cazenove, the noted cross-border M&A advisory shop, want to do that? I means really .....

PM11:21am

(I do wonder tho Bryce how many profit warnings you have caused corporate financiers to issue to their partners over the weekend)

11:21 am
BE11:21am

(Heh.)

BE11:21am

Have some names.

BE11:21am

 Beiersdorf: Maxingvest Group holds 51% of BEI shares, which would make any potential acquisition difficult as the family has been averse to any sale. Portfolio optimization opportunity: Tesa, an industrial adhesives business, is distinct from BEI’s Consumer business and could potentially be used as a financial asset should the board decide to pursue a large-scale deal in cosmetics.
 Henkel: Some 61% of voting rights are held by members of the Henkel family under a share-pooling agreement. Portfolio optimization opportunity: Henkel has continued to fine tune its portfolio by selective acquisitions across Laundry and Adhesives and remains open to acquisitions in the Cosmetics space (it had an interest in PG’s Professional hair care business).
 L’Oréal: Ms Bettencourt Meyers’ family owns 32.99% of the shares, with 23% owned by Nestle. Portfolio optimization opportunity: As a global leader in cosmetics, L’Oreal has continued to target bolt-on acquisitions to fill in the niches while also recently deciding to dispose The Body Shop, which has been underperforming.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

 Reckitt Benckiser: JAB, Reckitt’s largest shareholder owns c8% shares, having diluted its holding as it focused on consolidating coffee assets. RB is currently in the middle of acquiring Mead Johnson (covered by Ken Goldman) for c$17bn. Portfolio optimization opportunity: We have argued recently that, as Reckitt focuses more on its strategic Health & Hygiene franchise, potential disposals could help it to de-lever faster post the MJN deal. We see potential disposals of Food and Home, in the mid-term, even though we believe Food is the most likely to be disposed, as this would involved the least disruption to the business (we think the Home brands are more integrated within the overall RB platform).
 SCA: AB Industrivärden holds 29.6% of the voting rights and Norges 8.6%. Portfolio optimization opportunity: SCA is in the middle of splitting the company into two, focusing on Consumer Hygiene and Forest Co on a standalone basis. We highlighted recently that, in Aug-16, Dagens Nyheter reported that SCA had received bids for its Forest business, which SCA declined. Meanwhile, Dagens Industri reported that private equity firms are interested in buying the Hygiene Co. SCA has maintained that it remains focused on a potential split and does not comment on such reports.
 Danone: MFS (Massachusetts Financial Services) group holds 10.9% of Danone’s voting rights and said on 29 April 2015 that it did not plan to acquire control of Danone, nor did it intend to request the appointment of a member of the Board. In 2007, we saw press reports suggesting potential interest from PepsiCo in acquiring Danone, a possibility that was fended by the French government at the time. Portfolio optimization opportunity: Danone is in the middle of its acquisition of WWAV (expected to close Q117), while the company recently announced an additional €1b savings program by 2020.

BE11:22am

Nestle: Market cap of US$230bn, no single shareholder owns more than 5% of shares or voting rights. Portfolio optimization opportunity: Nestle announced last year its plan for a ‘new structural savings’ program to deliver 200bps of savings by 2019/20 even as the company continues to optimize its portfolio, e.g. the disposal Davigel in 2015, the European ice cream JV with R&R, and fixing its Frozen foods business in the US. In his first message to investors, new CEO Schneider poured cold water on suggestions that Nestle might engage in any meaningful corporate M&A for now amid elevated multiples in the sector and as portfolio optimization was currently a low priority.

BE11:22am

So, yeah, that's all of the sector.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Perhaps the most interesting one is Reckitt, of course. They of the strategically questionable baby-food deal.

PM11:23am

Oh you are so after them

BE11:24am

I'm saying it's pursuing a strange and unconvincing deal that's about 10 times the size of any previous deal they've done, and it's for .......... any number of reasons .........

11:23 am
BE11:24am

........ around which we can speculate.

PM11:24am

But which may or may not involve the trigger point for executive bonuses

BE11:25am

Hm. Or, indeed, there's the not entirely impossible idea that they're bulking up on baby food, so to speak. Making a poison pill out of infant milk.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

........ though the weekend press says -- and who knows wFeltcollaredsourcew they got the idea? -- that Kraft doesn't want HPC as a new category, so ................

Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC (RB.:LSE): Last: 7,019, down 81 (-1.14%), High: 7,114, Low: 6,983, Volume: 471.44k
BE11:26am

Anyway, that's enough of that.

11:26 am
undefined
PM11:26am

We haven't tackled the GBK attraction argument

PM11:26am

And we are not going to

11:26 am
PM11:26am

Too may moving parts

PM11:26am

Kadhim';s threatening a post

PM11:26am

later

11:26 am
PM11:27am

But it's clearly not Brexit = UK plc up for sale

PM11:27am

(For a start Unilever has circa 60% of its sales into emerging markets

PM11:27am

)

11:27 am
PM11:27am

(And Uk stocks rallied with sterling's fall)

BE11:28am

Well, yes. The "UK PLC for sale" angle was another bit of weekend pressery that was a bit ..... Can I say rubbish without offending any of my peers? Probably not.

undefined
11:28 am
PM11:28am

Can't help but notice Pearson while glancing at Unilver at the top of the fallers board

PM11:28am

Pearson being in the no2 slot

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 640.50, down 28 (-4.19%), High: 672.50, Low: 637.50, Volume: 1.85m
11:28 am
PM11:29am

What's fresh here?

BE11:29am

Berenberg. Selling down to 400p.

PM11:29am

Ouch!

11:29 am
PM11:29am

You know there are still people round the top table at the FT holding this stuff

BE11:30am

Shame. So there's lots of Pearson pre-results comment around but Berenberg's probably the most interesting of it.

BE11:30am

The idea here is a familiar one: core market terrible, ways out not obvious.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Debt creeping higher, costs getting tougher to cut.

BE11:31am

Your quick routes out are a sector merger or a PE buyout. Both of which Berenberg says make very little sense.

BE11:31am

Here's the upshot of it.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

● Pearson has a major problem: In fiscal 2015, higher education courseware contributed 40-45% of group EBIT. This key division faces serious structural and cyclical issues, which will continue until industry profits have normalised at much lower levels. We do not see a short-term fix.
● Leverage is higher than assumed: With returns likely to have impacted 2016 year-end cash flows, and the new strategy affecting cash flow in future, leverage is higher than the market thinks. We note recent negative statements by both Moody’s and S&P. Thus, Pearson is unlikely to return any cash to shareholders following a sale or recapitalisation of PRH.
● Is there opportunity for more cost savings? Pearson has already spent £610m on two restructurings in the last five years, yielding cumulative savings of £586m, before cumulative reinvestment of £100m and normal cost inflation. We do not see further opportunities for major savings, other than via cuts that would negatively impact the core business, such as reducing the size of the salesforce

PM11:32am

Only two restructurings in five years?

PM11:33am

I think for people working at Pearson it's been one restructuring that has so far lasted five years

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Well ..... I think there's only two it explicitly told the market about. As in, given them names.

BE11:33am

Restructurings are a bit like hurricanes. It's often a bit windy, but unless it has a name then it's not a hurricane.

BE11:34am

And sorry about that analogy, Murph. I know it's a sensitive subject.

11:34 am
PM11:34am

(of don't remind me of Cyclone Dineo. terrible terrible damage to my holiday hut)

BE11:05am

You'll be amazed to hear that we have tech problems.

BE11:34am

● We do not see industry consolidation as likely: Pearson is market leader (with a c40% share) in US higher education courseware, an industry that is already highly consolidated; we therefore do not see anti-trust authorities approving further concentration, which might have generated meaningful synergies in the event of a deal. The K-12 courseware and testing markets are also oligopolies, again suggesting anti-trust issues.
● What about private equity? With no easy cost savings, relatively high leverage, and no potential to sell a cleaned up Pearson to a competitor, we think private equity will steer clear. Anyone buying Pearson must have a clear view of how to fix higher education, and how to do it quickly. Private equity is hardly getting rich quick on the back of this industry – see McGraw-Hill and Cengage results – which won’t encourage new investors.
● Could a breakup work? The problem is that so much of group profit is declining. This is not a case of cutting off a diseased limb: it is a diseased body. If Pearson sold its attractive assets – Connections Education and Embanet, for example – it would be even more reliant on the declining higher education asset. Conversely, a sale of that unit looks very unlikely.
● Reducing price target again: Following a reassessment of the cash flows, we are reducing our price target further. The recovery in the share price reflects misplaced optimism as to the company’s ability to restore profitability, in our view. Ahead of Friday’s results, we reiterate our Sell rating and set a new price target of 400p.

11:35 am
PM11:35am

That pretty aggressive

PM11:35am

Lower than Liberum's target I think

undefined
11:35 am
PM11:35am

Sticking with the fallers...

PM11:35am

Bovis -- top of the 250 fallers

BE11:35am

Yeah, they're going to build fewer houses.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Because what Britain needs right now is fewer houses.

BE11:36am

FY misses. Largely on margin, which runs well below the sector average.

PM11:37am

Bottom end of what they indicated at the end of December

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Guidance is that they're slowing building by 10-15% this year because of operational issues

PM11:37am

Finals here btw http://www.investe...1702200700102482X/

BE11:37am

Should note the backdrop here that they lack a CEO, of course.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

You'll remember the Schroders idea from last month that Bovis should merge with Berkeley .....

PM11:38am

hmmmm

BE11:39am

.............. Suggested at the time that it looked a bit of a desperate proposal from someone who was long and wrong.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

And there's not much today to change that view, really.Here's Peel Hunt.

BE11:39am

Full-year results. Full-year PBT of c£155m missed the revised guidance of £160m-170m and compares with £160m in 2015. Operating margins slip 210bp to 15.2%, leaving them 350bp behind the sector average. Revenue was slightly better than expected at £1,055m, although the volumes and ASP were only marginally better, indicating higher other sales than expected. The dividend has been increased 13% to 45p (vs 44p est)

BE11:40am

Balance sheet and land bank. The group finished the year with net cash of £39m vs our estimate of £18m. However, the land held in the land bank shrunk by 6% to 18,700, well short of our estimate of over 21,000. The land bank has now shrunk to 4.7 years from 5.0 years and compares with the sector average of over 5.2. On top of this, the group has c25,500 strategic plots.
Outlook and forecasts. Guidance for 2017 has been cut hard with volumes now expected to be 10-15% below this year's level (which implies a 15-20% reduction on our estimates) as the business sorts itself out. We struggle to see how margins can move forward, whilst this process of rectifying the problems is going on, which means PBT forecasts are likely to come back 15-20%. Management has committed to paying the same level of dividend (45p) in 2017.
Performance and valuation. Until today, the shares hadn’t performed that badly vs the sector due to bid speculation offsetting the profit warnings. In our view,
the likelihood of the company being bought by any other industry players looks remote giving the liquidity in the land market. Therefore, the key to the shares performing better will be the group’s ability to turn itself around operationally. Without knowing who the CEO will be to lead this charge, we see no need to get involved especially given the wide choice of other attractive housebuilders.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

And Canaccord, since we're here.

BE11:41am

2016 results are below the recent guidance of £160 to £170m, due to a £7m customer care provision which resulted in PBT of £154.7m. As expected, 2016 numbers were negatively impacted by production process problems, with these results giving a bit more clarity on the costs of dealing with these issues suffered in 2016. There is a clear message in the statement that the group understands the issues and is busy rectifying the 2016 completion issues, addressing weaknesses in the production processes and customer care, and views 2017 as a year in which to reset the business. Clearly, it will take time to successfully address these issues and volumes are being guided down around 10-15% in 2017, which will adversely impact cash and profits in 2017. In the medium term, the key issue is what this business is capable of delivering in terms of volumes and returns from its land bank. At this stage, visibility over these issues is very poor. The balance sheet ended the year with net cash and management has committed to paying a flat (45p) DPS in 2017, which should provide some valuation support. Consensus for 2017 looks too high currently and we expect it to fall at least 10-15%. We prefer other names in the sector for yield and growth characteristics.

PM11:41am

(Soundbuy -- my Telegraph-reading mum saw that. That is north of our place and quite remote. Price will have come back a bit now, i suspect...)

11:41 am
BE11:42am

NAV/share for 2016 was 757p and the group has committed to a 45p DPS for 2017. If the shares trade on c.1 times book and a c.6% (sector average) dividend yield, it would imply a share price of c.750p.
Over the medium term, we believe the opportunity remains to drive a higher rating if returns are improved from the land bank. But, given recent slip-ups, the market is likely to want more evidence of any potential improvement to drive a re-rating and of the quality within the land bank.

undefined
PM11:42am

Just reading Neil Collins comment on Bovis from a few weeks back

11:42 am
PM11:42am

No incentive to help others

The 2015 annual report from Bovis Homes devotes 15 pages to directors' pay. Its magnificent mixture of thresholds, incentives, targets and rewards is a triumph of the remuneration consultant's art. With hindsight, however, it is possible to see a few cracks, rather like those appearing in some of the company's new homes.

Those stories of botched work and unfinished houses which produced the "Bovis house of horrors" headlines are reminiscent of the days before Polish workers transformed the building trade. The telltale crack in the remuneration report is the CEO's failure to earn his customer service bonus.

A year ago Bovis shares were already worst-in-class in its peer group. This raised the pressure on the executives, and the result was the Christmas fiasco of bribing customers to buy unfinished homes in a doomed attempt to avoid missing an arbitrary target. Russ Mould of AJ Bell Investment suspects the bonus structure with its reward for return on capital is to blame.

Well, maybe. The long-serving CEO has now gone and the company is promising another pay review. Bovis has achieved the baleful double of lousy share performance in a housebuilding boom and delivering a sub-standard product. Those carefully-crafted incentives benefitted neither shareholders nor customers. So cui bono? Oh, wait a minute...

PM11:42am

He's a very nice, waspish writer, Neil

undefined
11:42 am
PM11:43am

Phew

BE11:43am

We can stick to sellside, since there ain't much else.

BE11:43am

US is on holiday this afternoon

11:43 am
PM11:43am

President's day

PM11:43am

ha

BE11:44am

Isn't it Presidents' Day? Rather than President's Day? I mean, I guess the current Potus could adjust the possessive apostrophe to make it about him .....

11:44 am
BE11:44am

.... though I doubt he understands possessive apostrophes. Anyway ......

Rolls-Royce Holdings PLC (RR.:LSE): Last: 699.95, up 33.95 (+5.10%), High: 705.00, Low: 683.50, Volume: 3.14m
PM11:45am

Blimey that's quite a move

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Goldman pushing.

BE11:45am

Haven't read beyond the exec sum, which looked familiar.

BE11:46am

As in, cash will pick up. Eventually.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Rolls-Royce has the potential to substantially increase FCF between now and 2020 in our view. We believe the building blocks of this performance can already be seen. A complicated accounting set-up and reporting changes that impede earnings have refocused investor attention on cash flow – in this report we outline why we think cash flow can improve substantially and the most appropriate way to value this. Our revised 12-month price target of 1030p implies 55% upside, we upgrade the stock to Buy (from Neutral) and add it to the Conviction List.

BE11:47am

See? Familiar.

BE11:47am

We have remodelled the group’s flagship Civil Aerospace division on a cash EBITDA basis, that is, before the effect of TotalCare accounting adjustments and the capitalization of engine losses. This EBITDA bridge to 2020 (Exhibit 3) illustrates the underlying earnings growth potential within the group’s wide body franchise. Through the period we expect engine aftermarket payments to grow as the group accelerates the rate at which it sends engines into service, particularly on TrentXWB. This operating leverage dynamic from the aftermarket should more than offset higher engine losses and maintenance costs according to our model, as TrentXWB losses will fall, loss per unit on other engines will be stable and the number of shop visits will remain broadly unchanged given the pull-ahead effect seen recently on Trent1000. The Civil Aerospace division, we estimate, delivered £428 mn in EBITDA in 2016. By 2020E we expect this number to be c.£1.8 bn; looking beyond 2020 we believe the group’s FX exposure could add close to £1 bn of EBITDA in the Civil Aerospace division. Over the same period we expect investment spend to remain broadly stable (capex c.£1 bn pa) as legacy investment in new facilities is replaced by new tooling spend and the next generation of Aerospace technologies (Advance and ‘UltraFan’). Finally, in the absence of a clear end market improvement in Merchant and Offshore, Oil and Gas earnings growth in the non-Aerospace divisions is driven by announced savings plans in our view.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Rolls-Royce generated £100 mn of company-defined FCF in 2016, and has guided to stable performance in 2017. Therefore the current equity value (£13 bn) already reflects a degree of cash flow improvement. We value the company on EV/DACF (debt adjusted cash flow), on 2018 estimates, equating to a 12-month price target of 1030p. We use a multiple of 11.4x, derived from a returns (CROCI) based valuation screen. On a more simplistic screen our price target implies 8% FCFe yield and 14x P/E in 2020E; if we were to incorporate the additional FX benefit, which we believe should come through in 2021-23E, these would change to 12% and 9.3x, respectively.

BE11:49am

As is often the case with Goldman, the charts are better than the text (which I'm increasingly convinced is made to be read by machines, not humans). Here's the six-chart summary.

BE11:50am

......................... godalmighty my computer's slow.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

BE11:50am

There. Got it in the end.

PM11:51am

Interserve PLC (IRV:LSE): Last: 244.50, down 90.75 (-27.07%), High: 294.25, Low: 243.00, Volume: 3.89m
11:51 am

PM11:51am

11:52 am

BE11:52am

11:52 am

BE11:53am

PM11:54am

(Alchemy30 -- sorry too chaotic at the end of last week. Will grab him today.)

11:54 am
BE11:54am

This is the contract Interserve had a conscious decoupling with in November, by which I mean it was kicked off by Glasgow Council.

BE11:54am

I think the shares went up on that news. That response looks .... imperfect, in retrospect.

BE11:55am

Canaccord incoming.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Waste from Energy

BE11:55am

Solid work, analyst Matthew Walker. Top headline.

PM11:56am

hehehe

11:55 am
BE11:56am

In our initiation note last week, we flagged the likelihood of increased provisions being taken on the group's Energy from Waste (EfW) contracts following the termination in November of the group's Glasgow contract with Viridor. Today these provisions have been revised upwards from the £70m outlined in May 2016 to £160m, given a lengthy litigation period is anticipated on the Glasgow contract and that the group is unlikely to recover some costs from subcontractors given the largest, Energos, has fallen into administration. As with all construction contracts, whether there will be any further revisions remains an unknown given warranties and final account claims which may follow. Whilst period-end net debt for 2016 (guide of £270-280m remains) has offset the cash impact through beneficial working capital movements, average net debt has widened to £390m. With £60m of further cash outflows attached to the statement today, average net debt for 2017 is anticipated to be £450m with the group expanding its debt facilities by £66m as a result. On the call management indicated it would expect a smaller gap between period end and average debt in 2017, suggesting some likely reversal of period end working capital gains.

BE11:56am

Given the proximity to the group's results, due to be announced on 28 February, it is difficult for management to comment more fully on several points that are key to the investment case - predominantly around dividends, working capital and cash. With the group currently yielding over 7% on consensus for 2017E against a PE of less than 5x, we anticipate questions around dividend sustainability to remain. Whilst only amounting to c£37m in cash, the group could well look to revise this in light of the EfW commitments in the next two years particularly given an expected change in CEO over the next six months which may drive a wider review.
Ahead of any formal update we move our DPS estimates down to 16.2p (i.e interim/final dividends flat, c5% yield) and hold this level for the next two years, in order to maintain Net debt/EBITDA at 2.0x for FY17E.
Whilst working capital has been used to offset the cash impacts this year, we also believe that this movement may show some some reversal in 2017, with net debt expanding to £350m at Dec-17E despite reduced dividends.

BE11:57am

Ahead of the Group's results announcement, trading is likely to remain volatile as witnessed by the fall this morning. Within our previous potential 2017E SOTP valuation of 445p we had used an average net debt figure of £360m; simplistically revising this up to the £450m guided today would reduce our potential SOTP valuation by 13% highlighting the potential value with a PE of 4x currently. Our target price of 350p had not used this methodology given our perception of the short-term risk, utilising 8x EV/EBITA (a 10% discount to peers) instead.

BE11:59am

The proposal envisages an end to RBS’ 7-year struggle to divest W&G. Instead, an “independently administered” fund would be created to provide “dowries” to enable eligible challenger banks to increase their business banking capabilities. RBS will take a £750m provision in Q4 2016, which raises our forecast 2016e Attributable Loss to £6.3bn and cuts our 2016e tNAV to 304p (from 310p). We anticipate some “relief” today.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

RBS’ project to fulfil its State Aid commitments in relation to Williams & Glyn has (thus far) been quite painful. Circa £2bn has been spent on its (now abandoned) plan to create a standalone bank to IPO, and RBS had already disclosed that it will not be able to achieve the mandated separation and divestment by 31 Dec 2017. Any planned return of “surplus” capital is on ice.

In this context, almost any deliverable “remedy” has attractions. RBS will take a £750m provision in Q4 2016 (against which it will not achieve a full tax offset) and it anticipates further (unquantified) “reintegration” costs in 2017/18.

BE11:59am

We will review our more detailed forecasts in conjunction with RBS’ 2016 results due this Friday (24 Feb). In the interim, we increase our forecast Attributable Loss to £6.3bn in 2016e, (previously £5.7bn), and we cut our forecast for 2016e tNAV per share to 304p (from 310p) vs 352p in 2015. We continue to forecast a tenth successive annual loss in 2017e with a return to profit in 2018e, and we modestly raise our 2018/19e forecasts to reflect (1) the retention of the W&G business (for which we forecast a profit before tax of £320m in 2016e); and (2) the likely absence of a disposal loss.

One key beneficiary of the proposed “dowries” may be Virgin Money (Buy). Virgin placed its SME roll-out on hold in July 2016 but is (we think) now “re-incentivised” to proceed. Options for the “branch-free” specialist banks are perhaps less certain, though it is proposed that RBS will grant access to its branch network for business customers of challengers to facilitate “switching”.

Trading on 0.8x 2016e tNAV with, we think, no return to profit before 2018e, our Sell rec is maintained. However, we raise our TP to 225p (from 205p).

BE12:01pm

The proposed RBS deal is positive for the group in our view. W&G earnings if retained are c.9% of consensus expectations in 2018 - but with an incremental capital cost to the company relative to expectations of c.94bps. This represents 11% return on capital compared to c.6% 2018e (RBC estimate). RBS trades at 0.8x 2018e TBV. The new proposals to enhance SME banking could have a positive impact on those Challengers exposed to corporate lending - which as a proportion of balance sheet in order are CBG; MTRO; SHAW; ALD; CYBG (VM and OSB have no exposure and PAG is building into the business).

BE12:01pm

We expect the transaction as proposed could have a positive impact on consensus valuations. Within our forecasts currently (which are close to consensus) we expect £500m of restructuring costs from W&G (c.21bps of capital); separation in 2018 with a reduction in RBS' RWAs of £10bn (c.62bps of capital); and no further earnings from W&G from 2018 (c.£350m pre tax, c.9% of group consensus PBT). As guided by RBS the restructuring costs should continue but RBS retain the RWAs and W&G earnings, in exchange for a £750m provision (c.32bps of capital). Therefore, relative to consensus expectations, the deal would add 9% to consensus earnings but an incremental negative impact to capital of 94bps (32bps provision and 62bps from retained RWAs). At a net level this represents c.11% return on capital- which compared to 6% 2018 ROTE is a positive in our view.

RBS has said that dividend distributions will not resume until W&G and US RMBS litigation are settled and this is another step towards putting the biggest issues behind the company. However, Q3 pro forma capital ratio for this provision and the RMBS announced provision at 13.3% leaves little excess capital to the 13% capital target which the company has.

BE12:02pm

BE12:02pm

In a statement over the weekend, RBS indicated that it will offer a revised package of remedies to promote competition in the market for banking services to small and medium enterprises (“SMEs”) in the UK (instead of disposing of Williams & Glyn), including:
A fund, administered by an independent body, that eligible challenger banks can access to increase their business banking capabilities.
Funding for eligible challenger banks to help them incentivise SMEs to switch their accounts from RBS, paid in the form of “dowries” to eligible challenger banks.
RBS granting business customers of eligible challenger banks access to its branch network for cash and cheque handling, to support the measures above; and
An independent fund to invest in fintech to support the business banking of the future.

RBS indicates that it is undertaking this revised remedy package to “provide a path to increased competition in the SME market place” and will take a “£750 million provision within its 2016 Annual Results” which represents RBS’s “best estimate of the cost of the above package of remedies at this juncture.”

BE12:02pm

This remains subject to approval from the European Commission. If adopted, this alternative plan would replace the existing requirement to achieve separation and divestment by 31 December 2017 of Williams & Glyn.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Our take: this is positive for the specialty lenders/challenger banks that we cover, especially those without (or with small) branch networks, such as Aldermore, Close Brothers, OneSavings Bank, Paragon and Shawbrook. According to the most recent loan book disclosures, Aldermore, Close Brothers and Shawbrook have the most SME exposure, but Paragon is developing a SME franchise. The specialty lenders/challenger banks are scheduled to report as follows, and we will seek further guidance from their potential participation during their respective presentations:
Metro Bank: 2016 results on 22 February.
Aldermore: 2016 results on 2 March.
Shawbrook: 2016 results on 7 March.
Close Brothers: H1/FY17 results on 14 March.
OneSavings Bank: 2016 results on 16 March.
Paragon: H1/FY17 results on 23 May.
